awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Evolution of fine-scale recombination landscapes
awd_abstract_narration:
Meiotic recombination is the process by which genetic information is exchanged between paired chromosomes during gamete formation. This exchange is central to reproductive success and the generation of genetic variation, thereby providing the raw material for evolutionary change. If recombination goes awry, gametes can be formed with missing or extra copies of genetic information. Such chromosomal errors are the leading genetic cause of fetal loss, mental impairment, and developmental disability in humans. The number and location of recombination events varies within and among species for largely unknown reasons. This project will examine what determines variation in the frequency and chromosomal region of recombination events. Educational efforts associated with this research provide training in genetics and bioinformatics for students belonging to under-represented groups at different grade levels.

One goal of the project is to determine the nature, extent, and genetic basis of intra- and inter-specific variation in the distribution of meiotic recombination events along a chromosome using a combination of classical genetics and next generation sequencing. Computer simulations will be used to determine the consequences of this spatial variation in the distribution of recombination events for patterns of genetic variation within and between species. Finally, bioinformatics approaches will be used to determine how crossover distribution changes in response to natural selection. Broader impacts of this work include training of students and a postdoc, broad dissemination of the results, generating recombination data that will be valuable to the community, and working with the NC Museum of Natural Science to communicate our work to the public.

por.por_cntn:
This work was focused on recombination rate variation. We were interested in understanding the nature, extent, and genetic basis of polymorphism and divergence in recombination rate. We were also interested in understanding how recombination responds to selection. The educational plan for the proposed work focused on increasing representation in the sciences. There are several scientific outcomes from the funded work which have been disseminated through publications, conference presentations, and invited talks at other universities. The outcomes from the educational plan include an inventory of inclusive excellence programs within the division of natural sciences, and a new class that helps undergraduates navigate the process of applying for graduate study.

An important component of the work is the SCORE program. 

SCORE (Students of Color Opportunities for Research Enrichment; uoscore.org) is year-long, academically-based, hands-on research course for minoritized students early in their academic career. The program was developed by a former graduate student at the University of Oregon who recognized a lack of infrastructure to support minoritized students who wanted to participate in research. There are ample data indicating that retention of minoritized students in STEM can be bolstered by 1) early exposure to research and 2) community-building. The SCORE program was founded on these two principles. 

In the first quarter of the program, students are broadly exposed to scientific research. They tour research labs, and learn about the scientific method, model organisms, and how to effectively read a primary research article. In the second quarter, students conduct a research experiment and in the third quarter the students learn how to analyze the collective data and work together to write an abstract and make a poster to present at the UO Undergraduate Research Symposium. In the Spring quarter students also learn about research opportunities on and off campus and when needed, I help facilitate connections between SCORE students and faculty for lab placement. 

The experiment in which the students engage during winter quarter is driven largely by student interest. The last year SCORE was offered, we investigated the abundance and diversity of bacteria living on surfaces in dining establishments on and near campus. Students cultured bacteria from around campus, amplified DNA using PCR and sequenced a DNA barcode to identify the species living on the various surfaces that were sampled. Students learned data analysis and presentation skills. Previous experiments include determining the effect of additives (caffeine, hot sauce, probiotics) in fruit fly media on the fly microbiome, the distribution and abundance of different Drosophila species in Eugene, and bacterial preference in C. elegans.

One research associate and two graduate students were trained as part of this work, and 74 students came through the SCORE program.

Modified by: Nadia Singh
